description:
This is a good spot to grab a quick coffee and pastry, or maybe a sandwich. My favorite thing about this place is the wide selection. There are so many different pastries and drinks to choose from. They also have some sandwiches and other items that are made to order, but I like to stick to the quicker stuff straight from the case. 

My absolute favorite thing to get here is the turkey and Brie croissant. It's excellent and so delicious! I also like the little sandwiches and the bread pudding. All very tasty!

The atmosphere is nice too, with a lot of seating and free wifi!
author: Nicole D.

description:
Friends and I took a quick pit stop here for coffee before our drive to Napa.
They offer a great variety of baked goods, light meals/sandwiches and caffeinated beverages. My friend got their mango lemonade, which is DELICIOUS.
I wasn't too impressed when they forgot my London fog in spite of not being that busy.
author: Geetika B.

description:
I really want to like this place. It's easy to grab after a workout on union street, or if you need something quick. Their food is just so lack luster. Don't go here expecting an amazing breakfast- they're essentially reheating pre cooked eggs, which is kinda gross if you think about it. 

I will say their croissants are good. I've had their almond one and their ham and cheese one and both are good, but not something I would get on a normal basis (they are def not good for you). 

One grip- don't come here for coffee. They give you a huge glass bottle of iced coffee with a tiny cup of ice if you ask for it. Then, you're stuck with a half empty iced coffee and a tiny plastic cup with a straw that's too big for it. Goto Starbucks for your coffee if you're contemplating going here for it. 

I will still come here purely out of convenience on a need be basis, but there's plenty of other places nearby that are better.
author: Morgan J.

description: I was pretty confused about this "Boulangerie." The company got acquired by Starbuck's and then the owner bought the company back from Starbuck's. That's what the person working there told me. I like this Boulangerie, but I guess it's rebuilding now. So I think I would come back here. It is a nice French pastry/baked goods shop to get a snack from. They have sandwiches that I would get. The drinks are okay too, but I don't need a sippy from there. This one is on Union and it was pretty busy. If you were from Europe and around Union, this could be a place to go. And I know because I talked to some people from Europe who were here for Dreamforce. I really do like French pastries/baked goods. I got a quiche Lorraine. They have a rewards program too. Good luck!
author: Denise C.

description:
When La Boulangerie used to be opened in Marin County, Strawberry Village, I practically lived there! I used to always order their fruit and yogurt and baked eggs.

I was sad to see La Boulangerie go but glad to know its not that far away, just across Golden Gate in San Francisco!

I don't come here often at all anymore, but when i do its a quick stop between appointments just because of the location, convenient. 
I usually stick with coffee and few pastries, which are still great just like i remember. 

I discovered their new bottled lemonade which comes in multiple flavors and so good/refreshing.
author: Galya T.

description: Such an awesome French cafe with killer coffee and croissants. I had the croque madame which is by far absolutely delightful and a must have. I loved their coffee and if I could have I would have eaten everything. Huge perks for being super friendly and trendy. Sometimes trendy equates with snobbery and I was greeted with happy smiles and welcomes. Definitely a must visit for SF!
author: Noel B.

description:
Order at counter and they bring the food to your table. When busy and ordering numerous items sometimes they get mixed up a bit.

Amazingly delicious mini sandwiches especially their chicken bahn with pork pate. OMG is it great.

Good baquettes.

Excellent coffee.

I can do without their omellete. It's not terrible but not great and their potatoes are not very good.
author: Vic M.

description: I got the smoked trout salad and sub with arugula. Also got the cappuccino. Everything was delicious. The staff is extra nice too. Will come back to try other salads and the quiches. The croissant pudding pastry looked like the next thing on my to-try list.
author: Noor M.

description:
This place is solid. I rate this place A-OK and a nice spot for a cup of coffee either inside our outside.

Is it what I expected after reading a NYT article about its founder Mr. Rigo who is doing so much in France to restore the artisan bakery? Not really, but it is now a Starbucks property and Mr. Rigo has left the business. It is almost like a French Boulangerie to be sure with much smaller baguettes, fewer sweets options, and fairly expensive prices for small plates compared to Paris or Limoges or Toulouse to be sure, but hey, this is San Francisco and the coffee was good, and the bakery items were solid. The coffee in the bowl is annoying and silly and I never saw it in Paris or Poitiers but hey if that big old bowl of latte is your thing then fine.  Mornings can be super busy as the work-out and spin cycle crews pack in here and tend to make it a loud vocal fry v up-talk place, but I found the afternoons were a good bet for a table, a bit of quiet, a coffee and croissant, and at that time of the day I could hear myself think or actually read a little bit.

I was a bit freaked out when I saw the Yelp pop up (April 2018) alerting readers to a low "food safety score" so that should be posted behind the counter and most places proudly display it.
author: Marc R.

description:
Since this place is near work, sometimes I like to stop by in the morning to grab a pastry or two. They have some of the most amazing types of croissants. You'll find classics like plain, almond, and chocolate. But then you'll also get ones that are topped with roasted squash and sage. 

I love that even when I don't get my pastries heated, they're still crispy and flaky on the outside. 

They have a big selection of pastries and breads for you to buy. Quiche, tarts, danishes, kouign amann. And generally there's more than one flavour available so you can pick what you like. 

This is the perfect place to grab breakfast or lunch. A lot of times people are just grabbing pastries and coffee to go. So there's usually a lot of places to sit and enjoy your food.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Well we went to version 1 before they sold out to starbucks which was phenomenal
Now the authentic recipes are gone.  No flaky croissants.  

Pain au chocolat. Meh. Basically 
Americanized.  Might as well call it Pillsberry or very current Betty Crocker. The other stuff like sandwiches and bread I find is well at Safeway bakery. 

Kinda ironic.  Now if want a good flaky croissant i can get that at starbucks.

.Dommage que les Français que j'ai vendus sur le dollar américain ne soient pas obligés de venir ici.
author: Steve T.

description:
Food tasted okay. The lower rating is for the following
1. A very low sanitation grade of in the lowest 5% - I did not see the grade in person but it shows up on Yelp when I open the restaurant. It might go away in a while if the store makes the suggested changes by SF sanitation. This is a preference - just knowing this, I would choose another place
2. Extremely slow service. It might have been just that particular day but there was only 1 barista and I waited for 15 min for a to-go cappucino
3. The cappuccinos are served in bowls - its a thing they so but the cappuccinos get really cold because of the surface area - which is why for my second I asked for a to-go. This is more a matter of choice. I relish my cappuccinos over sometime in a mug or cup so it needs to stay warm
4. The coffee is very average. I was jetlagged and needed another one so I got a second but next time I would go elsewhere
author: Vidushi S.

description:
Where to begin. I will start with, I used to LOVE  this cafe. Big bowls of excellent coffee,  great potatoes and omelettes...those were the good old days. 

Now, no. Just no. Horrific little reconstituted, brought back to life from the dead potatoe balls that are supposed to be breakfast potatoes. I have actually never seen such a thing before.  They have no flavor and have less personality. 

I know that I may be wrong, but the omelette's eggs are very 'I stayed at a cheap hotel and had the continental breakfast eggs that are made from powder'. 

The coffee is decent, hence the 2 stars. But for the love of, use real, fresh ingredients and get rid of the frankenpotatoes. This was an institution in an incredible location...I long for day's of old....
author: Wendi R.

description: Nothing special, good for grab and go if you have nothing better to eat. Just average. I got the croissant egg white breakfast sandwich (croissant, egg, turkey, avo...). Honestly just average and expensive for avg
author: Heather R.

description: Oh- my - goodness, Great place for something quick and delicious. I'm a huge coffee lover and coffee here Is amazing along with food. To much amazingness.
author: Mommy Q.

description:
Cute little wine/cheese and semi mini last minute making dinner pick up items. They have fresh bread, plenty of cheese to try. 

I enjoyed the back of the store, where they shelved unique beers and wines. Small trinket items for making dinner. This store is nestled nicely in a cute neighborhood
author: Edward R.

description:
Great place to go for something quick and easy. The caesar salad is really really good and so are the bottled coffee (try the cold brew, not the vanilla I posted). If you are looking for somewhere fast and easy this is the place to go. They have to go selections like potato salad and chicken curry salad, as well as some really solid menu items. Great place to study as well and not too loud. 

I would give this 5 stars, but they close wayyyy too early. I tried going to dinner there but they close at 5.
author: Katie G.

description: This place is expensive for breakfast you have to order at the counter with no service. The food is decent and the pastries are tasty- my favorite thing to order is the large bowl latte. I'm giving it 3 stars because it's the type of place that charges you $2.00 for a side of avocado which is the smallest little mushy sliver- you think they could be more generous when you are spending over $20 for a order at the counter egg and coffee kind of place. They also don't clean off the tables very often so I ended up sitting outside with a dirty table and finding pieces of hair flying on my plate. The staff has an attitude they don't care which I guess makes it more authentic! ;)
author: Lady N.

description: I used to come here quite a bit when it was that other name Starbucks bought, but now it has seriously gone downhill. Nothing here was stocked when i visited at 2pm on an unusually sunny Thursday in SF. Hardly anything in the case, no toilet paper stocked in the totally unkempt bathroom (i'm not from around this neighborhood...but apparently being fancy Marina people doesn't stop the patrons from peeing ALL OVER the toilet seat and the floor, even knowing there is someone in line to use the bathroom, and from leaving it a total mess in general). No half and half at the dirty condiment station, barely any sugar packets, or mustard, or anything else that's normally supposed to be there (jars mostly empty)... it wasn't even busy, maybe 5 patrons in the place. And now a food safety rating in the bottom 5% locally? Really? Gross. I hate to give my $ to Starbucks, but next time I'll just go there, it's right down the street a few steps, had a longer line in fact, but at least the employees seem to give a care. One extra star for a decent iced americano. Nothing to write home about. Plenty of other coffee joints on Union st. for you to choose from, all with pretty great coffee.
author: Theresa C.

description: I usually go to the Hayes Valley location, which I adore. In comparison the one is a disappointment. The service is slow and the people behind the counter lack a certain level of social grace. Not to mention that their pigeons in the restaurant as I type this waiting for my food. I would recommend visiting another option.
author: Amber H.

description: Food is good. Customer service not so much. The guy with the nice brows, not, one, smile, out of this guy. Not even a hello, thank you for coming, have a nice day. He said hi to the lady that walked in AFTER me. I won't be back.
author: D D.

description: My life revolves around food. I'm obsessed (just like the rest of the country) with good food. When I'm in SF which is often I make a bee line in the AM to the Boulangerie for my cheese danoise. It is slightly sweet and simply perfect. I like, you'll like, we like the boulangerie.
author: Rebecca R.

description: I love this location, I go almost weekly, but today I had a very unpleasant experience. You should not have someone who is clearly sick working the cashier, taking orders, touching credit cards with their infectious hands. This woman, who may be the manager, I see her there all the time, was clearly sick and than proceeded to sit right next to me as I was trying to enjoy my breakfast (which I never get to sit there & eat) & was coughing all over as I'm trying to eat. It was disgusting & unsanitary &  I had to box up my food & leave as I felt her germs all around me. I will not be going back to this location if you let your employees work in the food industry sick like this.
author: Andrea M.

description: This is a great place to get a latte or chai latte.  Great service, manager if the store is always ready to help. Place is immaculate and pastries are outrageous.
author: Carol B.

description:
Meh. Far from one of the best brunch places I've been to. In fact, I think I could have made something similar in my own kitchen... Customer service was also a bit appalling.

Let me tell you about my first (and probably last) experience here. I came to La Boulange to meet with a couple of friends after finishing a half marathon. I was starving, no doubt. I knew it would take me a little bit of time to walk there, so I asked my friend to order me the omelet on the menu (I looked up the menu beforehand) without ham. I arrived around 10-15 minutes after my friend finished ordering for me and honestly expected to sit down and have my food brought very quickly to me to satiate my insane hunger at the time... and unfortunately, I had to sit there while my friends finished eating their food and wound up waiting an additional 30 minutes before receiving my omelet. And....... when I got my omelet, low and behold, there was ham!!! I finally got my food and then found out that I couldn't even eat it!

I immediately took the omelet back to the kitchen and told them about the mistake. They told me that they were sorry and would get right on making a new omelet. So I'm waiting and waiting, so anxiously, for my correctly made omelet. I am ravenous now. 5 minutes pass... 10 minutes pass... 15 minutes pass.... still no omelet in front of me. I decide to go pester the kitchen again... and guess what? THEY FORGOT! The lady told me that she'd be right on it, and I finally got my food 5 minutes later. Totally unacceptable. I think I finished the omelet in a minute because I was so hungry. 

The omelet itself was pretty good, but if I had all the ingredients, I think I could have made the same thing - nothing super special. Serving size was small, especially for the price, and because of that, I don't think my brunch meal was worth it at all.

My friends said that the pastries here were better, so maybe go for those if you somehow find yourself here. The coffee drinks also look pretty unique since they're served in bowls. But just in my experience with the actual savory food, I was severely disappointed, and my tummy was left still hungry afterwards.
author: Sheila D.

description:
Food safty warning! I got really sick here with a cup of latte and a croquet madam sandwich this morning.  I've had nothing else today except what I ordered here. 

The service was horrible. The cashier had an attitude.  There were dirty dishes piling up. We had to bus our own table just to sit down. 

I used to be a fan but it's just not the same after Starbucks. Will not return after many years of patronage...very sad!
author: Cindy W.

description: We stopped in here during the Union Street music festival for a snack and some coffee. It was early afternoon and there was plenty of seating so we ordered and sat next to the windows to people watch. The coffee was fine, nothing special, however the Chai Latte was one of the best we have yet had in San Francisco. We ordered a quiche and a raspberry financier as well. The quiche was wonderful. The crust was flaky, the egg was creamy and rich, and the vegetables were flavorful. I was surprised by how good it was and had to stop myself from eating it all because we were sharing :) I would definitely come back.
author: John W.

description:
A little spot I come by every time I'm in the area. Just a few blocks is the marina and a few blocks on the opposite direction is pacific heights. 
They sell fresh baked breads, pastries, salads, sandwiches, soups, breakfast and they iced drinks/ espresso drinks. 
Cappuccino is delicious and I tried the pear almond financier and I love it, because I love almonds mmmm. It looks like a mini cupcake, but it's much more dense. 
The service was quick and with smiles plus it's always clean.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
It used to be my favorite and was probably the best cafe in the whole city without question before Starbucks bought it.  It is good, but it used to be amazing.  Below is a link showing it's fantastic pre-Starbucks days.  I am happy to see La Boulange making good efforts to come back after the Starbucks destruction (shut down) of La Boulange, but I hope La Boulangerie goes the extra mile to get back to its pre-Starbucks glory days or even better. It seems very clear that the whole purpose of Starbucks was to take away the greatness of the original La Boulange so that Starbucks gets their business.  See for yourself:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GHLYbN_PFaM
author: Bay Area Guy L.

description:
This place is the worst. Half the stuff is microwaved and the other half is trucked in from real bakers.

Today I thought "I'll skip the overpriced crappy food, get a side of potatoes and make eggs at home." For $3.80, I got 12 little potato bites. That's $.32 each. Pathetic.
author: Adam L.

description: I had the pleasure of eating breakfast here: got the breakfast egg and cheese with ham sandwich on a croissant with a side salad. Wow!!!  It was knock out of the park good!!! Every single bite. I used to frequent their location in Cole Valley while a grad student 15y ago and am so pleased to learn that their food and service across their various locations is as superlative as I remember and has stood the test of time. Thank you!!!
author: Laila D.

description:
Whenever I need a healthy salad fix on Union st., I head to La Boulangerie. 

Their smoked trout salad will make you want to eat salads ALL the time! Salty smoked trout, boiled red potatoes, creamy slices of avocado, lots of apples and cherry tomatoes on field greens, this combination just works so well drizzled with a lip pucking lemon vinaigrette. The walnut bread croutons add a nice crunch to the salad. I can eat this at least twice a week and won't get bored!

On sunny days, the bright orange chairs outside beckon you to sit down and people watch. Do it with an iced tea in hand. If you can't resist a sweet treat, they got you covered with the perfect personal sized pastries and baked goods. I don't indulge here on those because remember? I'm keeping it healthy!  #bigfatlie
author: Janice C.

description: Rating is for the service. They got my order wrong and I explained that it was incorrect.  Normally I'd just take whatever I get, but really wanted a cold drink (like the iced americano I ordered) and not a shot of espresso. They were super rude and treated me like I was trying to scam them lol. They eventually refunded for the original espresso and charged me for the iced coffee (fine, but this on top of dealing with the attitude from a misstep on their part). I think I'll just go to the pac heights one instead. ‍
author: Mandi M.

description: Oh how I love you, La Boulangerie and I love your smoked trout salad with all of its greens, avocado, tomatoes, apples and piece of bread - love it!  So filling, healthy and yummy!  I love you to pieces!!  Can you please open a spot in Union Square again - pretty pleeeeease?  :)  Thank you, merci beaucoup!
author: Maile N.

description:
La Boulange is back! (well, it's been a while now, but I'm still just as excited as I was when the news first broke). Though the name has changed to the new and improved "La Boulangerie de San Francisco", the food remains the same- which is definitely a good thing. There was a lot of drama surrounding the 2012 selling of the original La Boulange. San Francisco residents we're legitimately upset at the news, because it meant one of the staples of this city was disappearing, and for a pretty confusing reason.

The return of La Boulanerie was a pleasant and welcoming surprise. There was a realization by the owner of this popular chain that it's a needed part of daily life for so many people. Coming back to the Union location today for the first time since it's re-birth, I have to say that I feel the same way. The croissants are just as good, the open face sandwiches are as delicious as ever (see picture below), and the service still very quick.

During my visit, I opted for the Hummus sandwich with avocado, cucumbers and tomatoes. What a great decision that was! I've been a long time fan of this chain and have tried nearly everything on the menu, but today was a first, since I would typically go for protein based options. The hummus was very tasty- and I know my hummus! The addition of fresh cucumbers and tomatoes was perfect. It's a dish I highly recommend if you're looking for something light but filling.

Final verdict: La Boulange was more than just your average run-of-the-mill spot to get coffee, lunch and pastries. It was a staple of San Francisco where people came together to talk and socialize. With the return of La Boulagerie, that same feeling is back, and people are able to once again return to their regular routine.
author: Alex B.

description: Overpriced, very average food... every plate I've had is pretty bland, and today they forgot turkey on my breakfast sandwich, standard order. I paid $17 today for a small chai latte and a egg sandwich... for just 2 eggs, quarter of an avo, and a slice of cheese, $11 seems outrageous. I suggest going down to Squat and Gobble for better food and bigger portions with an outdoor patio...
author: Katie H.

description:
I really loved the old La Boulange standalone shops even when it was operating under Starbucks leadership. Their fruit tarts were so delicious and I would go out of my way to find them.

Then they closed the La Boulange stores but they've since re-opened a few of them as "La Boulangerie Patisserie". But everything just felt off. The blue and orange colors were there but the menu looked completely revamped. Even the fonts were different. The pastry case lacked a lot of the favorites I had before, but especially the fruit tarts. I hope it was just because I was there in the evening, but I have a feeling it's just permanently gone.

I got a chocolate ganache tart, which was tasty but still not exactly what I wanted out of this new La Boulangerie Patisserie.
author: Danielle C.

description: The Blueberry Cheesecake Kouign Amann was so delicious and the coffee was so good, probably the best of the coffee places I tried while there. Excellent house made vanilla syrup for the coffee as well!
author: Rachel T.

description: What a disappointment. Walked in to get some coffee, a pastry, and do some work on my laptop. Every table not occupied was covered with old plates and napkins--meaning you had to bus prior patrons' plates and napkins if you wanted anywhere to sit. I asked about WiFi access prior to purchasing, had a password printed on a receipt, only to then find out they don't have access from 11-1:00 for lunch... I get the concept, but let someone know this when they ask. All in all, this was the worst cafe experience I've had in the area, and will not be returning.
author: Kathryn B.

description: Walked past this place and it was decently busy so I decided to try it out. Got my order to-go and when I got home and opened it up there was a black hair. I decided to check yelp (should have done this first!) and there was a *warning* that La Boulangerie has a poor food safety score! (Bottom 5% locally)Surprise surprise. Also, they charge $2 to add bacon to the breakfast sandwich... $2 for ONE PIECE OF BACON. With so many options on Union St, I will not be returning.
author: Caitlin S.

description: For those who are gluten free and vegan try the seasonal greens salad with avocado instead of chicken and no bread (it comes with a slice of bread). It is filling and scrumptious! :) All the people who work at the boulangeries are wonderful! Thank you for doing what you do! :)
author: Sue S.

description:
So glad that this place is here.
I was taking my time to look around the area, shop and enjoy a good afternoon snack when I saw this place.  I was stoked.
Ordered me a latte, lemon meringue tart and some financier.
All of the pastries were great.  coffee---hmm.. it was okay.
The place is clean, had a lot of seats.
Service was okay.  the guy at the counter seemed tired and annoyed. I don't blame him.  the place looked busy.
author: Learnee L.

description: Love their pastry like the chocolate croissant and butter one too. This location is busy and their employee give me a lukewarm feeling. Not great people service. Most are a bit snobbish. I get more love from a stray dogs than most people here. Prices are a bit expensive and some items are not that tasty. If you expect to have room. You can forget about that. Tight space and the floor are always dirty.
author: S F.

description:
Meh. 
Given the long lines I thought the place was going to blow the socks off my feet. 
Instead, it was just meh. The french macarons were A-OK. Nothing to rave about. The tropezienne pastry my boyfriend and I shared was quite delectable. 
At 3pm they were running out of most pastries. Given that they stay open till 7pm I thought that was a sign of bad management. 

The cafe really came off as disorganized and not well kept.  The chairs and tables were sporadically located all over the cafe. The condiment bar  had a decent selection of complimentary sweets such as honey, nutella and some other jams.
author: Lana S.

description:
There was a patron sitting and eating and feeding bread crumbs from her plate to three pigeons. INSIDE THE RESTAURANT. I complained and a worker finally used a broom to get them outside. 

Food was alright.
author: Cameron C.

description: Strangely, they make the best americano coffee that I have had in SF. The pastries and sandwiches are very good and the baguettes are perfect. Only complaint is that they close early.
author: Leigh J.

description:
So glad this place reopened I've missed it! I've been coming here every since it opened here in Hayes Valley. I enjoy the friendly staff, grab and go menu, and just having a place in the hood to get delicious French pastries. It's also been a great meeting place for my business since its colorful and cannot be missed.
Welcome back La Boulangerie de SF to Hayes Valley!
author: Rhonel R.

description:
The good points: the drip coffee was fine, the bacon was crispy and, despite it being crowded at 9am on a Sunday morning, the staff were doing a good job of clearing tables as they became free.

The bad points: absolutely no GF options on pastries or cereals etc. - hence the order of bacon.  But $3.75+tax for a side order of bacon which comprised TWO strips was ridiculous - than equated to over $2 per strip of bacon - and it didn't have any gold leaf on it!

I ended up paying over $7 for a small coffee and two strips of bacon.

It seems that the new owners have upped the prices but not the experience.
author: Norman B.

description:
I read an article online that mentioned their almond croissants so i went to try it out despite my  negative perception created by the disastrous starbucks partnership. It was busy and i told them my order was to stay twice but they gave me a croissant in a bag and a paper cup. Once that was remedied, i was shocked to find out there was no wifi. what cafe doesnt have wifi these days?
The croissant was average at best, not flaky, sort of doughy. The latte was excellent. 
I would get a coffee to go next time and look for experience elsewhere.
author: hillary s.

description:
Dear sir--I should have asked for your name but you caught me off guard. Thank you for your kindness. You couldn't have known, but I was feeling pretty crummy about everything and your gift of an apple chausson really lifted my spirits.

It was delicious too.
author: Isabelle W.

description: Had higher hopes for a French Boulangerie but was sadly disappointed.   Mediocre, weak coffee, even with 3 shots a small size, served in a large soup bowl. A pain au chocolate that could have been from any American coffee shop.   C'est dommage.
author: R L.

description:
Great spot to drop in for breakfast on Mother's Day!  No reservations, tasty egg dishes and wonderful coffee and pastry.
Perfect for our limited time frame..
author: Chimene S.

description: On 10/14/2016 I was overcharged tip by one of the cashiers. I reported the incident to the credit card company.
author: Claudio B.

description:
I'm so glad that Pascal decided to bring La Boulange back. I've been coming to this location for quite some time now and was so happy that it reopened. I heard that most of the staff working here at the La Boulangerie were previously employed by La Boulange, that's great news.
My favorite ham and cheese croissant are my go to. It's really good and filling.
They have this new desert called choux, got variety of flavor as sweet treat.
It's the only place on Union Street that have variety and affordable food to choose from.
I'll definitely keep on coming back
author: Mary Grace C.

description: We come here each time we visit San Fran. Sad to see they don't offer macarons anymore (they were sooooo gooooood!) but we settled for the vanilla latte and it made up for our small sugar fix.
author: Kristin M.

description:
Came in late afternoon for a cappuccino and pastry. Service was friendly and prompt. The chocolate croissant was one of the best I've ever had. Seriously. So damn good. The cap was okay. It was huge, they served it in a bowl, which was slightly strange.

My huge compliant was that they left the front doors wide open the entire time I was there and it was freezing. Everyone in the dining area was complaining about it and wearing their jackets. I'm sure they get more customers walking in when the doors are open and I love the outdoors as much as the next person but geez, man, my feet were frozen by the time I left.

If they would warm it up, 5 stars for sure.
author: J J.

description: This is a must for your morning fix.  Walk past Starbucks and ease in.  Great cappicino served in a bowl.  Yummy.  Great pastries, eggs,  brioche, I could go on.  Service was great.  Friendly and fast.  Thanks
author: Dave J.

description:
Sigh.   It just isn't the same.  Not at all.   The menu has changed. The product has definitely changed and the quaint energy has left the building.  
I had the la boulangerie breakfast and it was just so sub par.  The potatoes I used to love here have now been substituted for a frozen deep fried potato product.  The eggs aren't organic.   So sad!  Was stoked they weren't gone , now wishing a new, truly SF breakfast spot was here.
author: T L.

description: Welcome back, La Boulange.  If you were a fan of the previous incarnation, you'll be really happy that the place is pretty much exactly the same as it was before.
author: Joanne G.

description: Beautiful for American French baked goods! We are so bummed that the one off of Fillmore Street closed. So sad as it was a wonderful place to grab breakfast or lunch. Too bad Starbucks bought them then destroyed them by shutting the doors. Please bring La Boulange back on Fillmore Street.
author: Kirk M.

description: Food is not fresh, the manager guy ( red hair ) are so rude and no respect to customers. Regardless of the worst service they ask for a tip even for a coffee. Even for daily customers zero respect and smile
author: Afag S.

description:
The time it takes to get a cup of coffee here is crazy. Not the lines. The actual time it takes them to pour you a cup. Then you have to carry your no-lid cup over 5 strollers to get to the lid just in time to realize you've missed the bus. 

PS - I think they also charge a $.50 credit card fee. I'd expect small businesses to put up a stink over credit cards (and understandably so), but large corporations (e.g. Starbucks in a quaint outfit) can get over it.
author: Aubrey O.

description: The pastries here are really good. All the egg dishes are horrible: The potatoes that come with the egg dishes are inedible and the bread that comes with the eggs is like cardboard. The coffee comes in bowls, not mugs, but big cereal bowls, where I guess you're supposed to drink it with a spoon?
author: Scott P.

description:
Horrible customer service. Stale pastries. 

Ordered and paid for an extra hot cappucino. It came out luke warm. Went back to the cashier, and she pointed me to barrista. The bearded barrista guy with piercing made me wait for few minutes and then said "we charge a $ extra for warming it".

Fucking rude.
author: Tim B.

description:
What happened?!

I used to LOVE the Boulangerie. Everything was delicious the atmosphere buzzing. But this last visit was so disappointing I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. The 'fresh' OJ was from a carton (don't tell me it's fresh if you didn't squeeze it!) my French toast (what used to be the best in the world) was dry, my friends potatoes tasted like dried cardboard balls. The staff didn't care. It felt like I was in a fast food joint ... Where has all the love gone?
author: Sam W.

description: This place is so close to home and I used to come here pretty much every second weekend for a fresh, tasty open faced sandwich breakfast. Even when they changed management to and away from Starbucks again, was still ok. However, this week they have totally changed the menu. Now it's bland, greasy and uninspiring. And the place is packed, so you still end up waiting for spare (and dirty) table, so you can eat your tasteless food. The takeaway pastries still look ok but I haven't tried to confirm. Honestly though, don't waste your time - I won't be.
author: Kylie F.

description: I'm happy to see La Boulange is back, if not in my neighborhood, at least in the next 'hood over. Just walked my dog there, dodging rolled up yoga mats all the way down Union. The interior looks the same as before, as does the menu, though prices are 35% higher than previously. Quality is also higher - I was consistently disappointed in their pastries before, but the buttery chocolate danish I had today was clearly a step up from the drier, more mass produced ones of the Starbucks (and maybe pre-Starbucks) era.
author: Nick C.

description: I read some reviews of this place that were less than flattering but I had a great experience here. Went early on a Sunday (9am) and there were some tables available. I ordered an almond croissant, which they heated up for me (no microwaves involved) and a chai latte. Both were excellent! Nice crowd there, not too noisy, but lively enough. I would highly recommend.
author: Phillip B.

description: I loved the original La Boulange and was excited when I found out it was coming back as La Boulangerie de SF. Unfortunately it hasn't lived up to the original. There are 3 main things that I wish they'd improve. (1) Please don't serve stale pastries. If it's early afternoon and the pastries are no longer good, throw them out instead of continuing to sell them (2) Please add the strawberry jam back to the condiment area (who eats marmalade?!) (3) Figure out a way to get and keep those dirty pigeons from freely roaming the restaurant floor.
author: Maria Y.

description: I love everything about la boulangerie and their menu. The staff is attentive and helpful. The food and drinks are delicious. It is so awesome that they reopened and aren't affiliated with that extremely  basic coffee shop from Seattle. Glad to have you back in my neighborhood boulangerie.
author: Emily L.

description: Love this place. Food is always so good. The homemade granola is delicious. They serve the coffees in cool bowls. Always pleased.
author: S H.

description:
Twee Tea at Boulangerie

Iced tea is $1.95 a cup for sale in the case next to the cashier.  As you can see in the photo the plastic cup is only filled up to the green line which is about an inch below the top.  The cup could have held a lot more tea.  Or ice, there was no ice.

I asked the very polite metrosexual cashier why the iced tea was not filled to the top.  He helpfully explained that it was filled to the "fill line".  How about refills? Nope.

The experience was so absurd I had to spend the $1.95 to post it here on Yelp.  $1.95 for a glass 3/4 full of slightly chilled tea.  And no refills.

Almost every restaurant and bar I have been to in SF has free refills for iced tea.  Boulangerie itself has had free iced tea refills in previous visits.

This is what happens when the restaurant's owner is not watching the store.  Utterly clueless employees with no sense of customer service get blithely stuck on stupid.
author: Fred F.

description: This used to be a top notch spot, even post Starbucks acquisition.  Now for $15 you get 2 coffees and 2 sandwiches.  They've kept the same names, like Turkey Brie sandwich.  But its made with half the portions (see pic of tiny pieces of Brie) and doesn't taste fresh the way it used to.  Poor job re-opening this spot.
author: Haley H.

description: Our group enjoyed an Americano, a Carmel Latte, and Latte. All excellent. For snack we enjoyed many of the desserts. They were all great. Especially the Salted Carmel Choux.
author: Mike B.

description: My experience here has been a mixed bag. Personally, I haven't had any issues. I've tried their delicious pastries (must try the almond croissant) and their Cobb salad (a little small, but very tasty) during a couple of different visits. The waiters have always been friendly and the service relatively prompt. However, my friend had a bad experience when we came here for brunch. She ordered an omelet without ham. The first time around they gave her the omelet with ham. Naturally she returned it and they were going to make her another one without ham like she had asked for. However after waiting for about 20-25 min, they still hadn't brought it out and when we checked on it, they had actually forgotten about it... So overall while I've personally had a good experience I feel the need to take a star off for the service. This place is super convenient for me to go to so I will likely go more often in the future and update my review as I do!
author: Jimmy C.

description: The menu changed and I don't know if I'll be back. What used to be my favorite place to grab a quick and delicious breakfast now has extremely limited options that you can find at 12 other brunch locations on the same street.The egg white sandwich ($10) consists of a sliver of tomato, fried egg whites, and one piece of avocado on soggy wheat bread. Do not order. The best items on the old menu (open faced salmon sandwich, French toast, oatmeal, and avocado toast with eggs) are no longer offered and the breakfast plates are more limited for the same price point. For 16 dollars you can have a lame sandwich and an iced coffee. Since reopening this place is a bummer.
author: Molly Q.

description: Delicious Madeline's and great customer service. I really like everyone working behind the counter... They always have a smile for me :)
author: Tina S.

description: Fantastic croissants -  definitely worth a visit if you want some nice chocolate hazelnut croissants with your coffee!
author: Praveen J.

description: Sorry to be incredibly negative but this place has gone way downhill since their reopening.  Service is twice as slow and everything is so cold after being heated up.  The sudden lack of organization is just remarkable.
author: Amber R.

description:
La Boulange Magic is back.
great job Pascal Rigo bringing back better quality ingredients.
one wish is to see the chocolat eclair back !
author: Alex D.

description:
This place is just that- A-OK.

I was shopping on Union St. in the afternoon and it was time for tea. I picked out a tea and a macaron (strawberry or pistachio maybe, I don't remember). The macaron was crap. It was stale and chewy. Garbage.

I thought the menu was rather overpriced for several food/meal type items. There were several people around me eating the open faced salmon cold plate sandwich. It looked fine. Service seemed a bit slow all the way around, and even for my order. And yes, I only ordered tea.

I would try this place again or another of its locations, but I'm not going to pay an arm or a leg or as the French would say 'coûter les yeux de la tête' for some of the menu entrees.
author: Stephanie H.

description: Don't ask for a side of eggs. They'll charge you for the full breakfast plate ($10+). When I went back and asked why not, the person at the cash register said that it's not possible to get a side of eggs. Don't know why she didn't say that in the first place. Also, what kind of brunch spot can't do a side of eggs? It's pretty basic
author: Greg N.

description:
So so good .. 
Coffee is served in bowl-like cups 
Great selection of breads 
They have Nutella in spreading menu 
Quick service
author: Olga M.

description: la bou does not dissapoint. my kind of food. quality, and not too big in quantity = quality over quantity = 5 star execution. fresh ingredients that do not leave you feeling bloated in regret. A+ recommended
author: Juls C.

description: These pastries are amazingly delicious, though I realize everyone already knows it. I had the pumpkin nut muffin which had wonderful fall flavors and was the perfect texture, not dry at all like most muffins. Need to go back to try the more traditional croissants, etc.
author: Hannah A.

description: I used to come here in the morning but I am no longer am interested in wasting my time (not money) here. Ive always loved their food and the coffee is much better since they've switched to equator. But the service is lacking in the most important places. I've witnessed staff placing blame on customers when approached with a mistake on their order. Whether or not it was the customer or cashiers fault, why not resolve the issue rather than feeding the fire. I feel the staff here is not being supported or being provided an efficient training regiment in order to provide general customer service. The staff seemed stressed during their time of high volume and I could not identify a manager on the floor supporting them.  This location is no longer a place I find to be sanitary when pigeons are constantly being chased out the store when a simple solution is to keep their only entrance shut. I am not saying they should be exterminated I only feel that the most cost efficient and simple solution is to leave the entrance closed.
author: Eva J.

description:
I live in Oakland yet drive to the city once a week to get mostly bread pudding at the Union Street store.  I think they do a great job there, and I buy about 10 to 15 pieces of bread pudding for my clients and friends.  I have to admit I keep about three for myself.  They are always very happy to box them up individually for me as they are mostly gifts.
This time I called a day ahead to make sure they would have the amount I was buying, in case they sold out by the time I got there.  Evan, the manager (who usually helps me) had them all boxed up and in two shopping bags waiting for me when I arrived.  I LOVE the bread pudding as do my clients and friends.  I think Evan really does a good job providing the best service anyone could ask for.  I go because I love the food, but he really takes great care of guests.  I just wanted to post this comment because they do a great job providing great food!!

David
author: David U.

description:
First the good.  The pastries at this La Boulangerie are good in comparison to others (I've been to many in this chain famously owned by SBux).  They managed to warm my chocolate croissant just right and my friend's apple turnover was also reported to be fresh- which is definitely more than what you could say for many of their sister storefronts.

Now the bad.  I could talk about how I had to clean my own table and furnish that table with chairs myself or the fact that it was overpriced and packed with people to the point of chaotic, but that's not the main problem for me.  This place has been issued a WEAK COFFEE ALERT.  Oh yes, my pet peeve.  And who wouldn't be peeved?  My friend ordered an espresso.  I took a look at it and- having had tens or hundreds of espressos at various La Boulangerie locations, I could tell it was not right.  It was about a third in quantity of what you would expect from a single espresso, and yet about as dark.  So skimping basically.  I took it back.  The barista told me this is a 'fixed amount'.  I said 'fix it'.  The manager came over in bright red lips, explaining that was already a 'long espresso' (all of a sudden, not the fixed amount).  She said she could have the barista (I really cannot call her that with a straight face) pull two shots through one.  I said, 'try it'.  As you can expect what came out was something like a cup of black coffee (although in the quantity of an espresso shot), and with a burnt-chalk aroma and taste.  As you could have guessed, she could not drink it.  We left it on the table.

Now for my black coffee.  I ordered a small cup of coffee as I have at many La Boulangerie locations.  Usually I find the black coffee from this establishment to be passable, although it took a sharp nose-dive after the SBux buyout.  I asked once and they responded:

It's an 'SBux blend' for the La Boulangerie chain.  Read:  the old one was too good and too expensive to produce.  Corners were cut and we charred some of our extra beans.  Voila!  A new specialty French roast!  Some one got a promotion for that.  Take it away.  

But back to this location on Union St., in the heart of the Marina district of San Francisco.  This coffee, even by humble comparisons, was extremely weak.  It literally tasted like hot water. I tried cinnamon.  Now it was hot water with cinnamon.  This is the first time I could not finish- or even really begin- to drink a black coffee from La Boulangerie. We left it on the table.

We went there for the location, but left for the unpleasant atmosphere and, worst of all, extremely unsatisfactory coffee.  They left with my money.
author: Marc M.

description: I love their pastries! I think that they they are better now than before they were Starbucks! I am happy to have a place familiar to me where I can simply relax and have a nice cup of coffee. Customer service is always friendly and I love their decor.
author: J C.

description: Open faced mushroom and tuna melt were mouthwatering good. Mushroom soup was a creamy savory yumminess. Onion soup, pretty good, but we like our homemade one better. Did not get to try any pastries boo. They looked so good. Try to go off hours or expect a wait for tables if you need seating.
author: Mary P.

description:
I love this place - did a Sat brunch and it was awesome! 

The environment is definitely busy, yet still fun people watching, descent service coupled with excellent food! One piece of advice, once you walk-in, especially if you are doing a Sat brunch (and you are not doing it alone, obviously) - split the party and have others go do some table stalking - they don't take reservations, and if everyone waits in-line to order - you will definitely be struggling for a table.  Best to divide and conquer! Table turnover is good - we waited for about ~10mins, not too bad for a Saturday.  

Everything looked excellent - I did the scrambled egg sandwich and it was made to perfection!  Tasted the egg frittata, it was also really good.  Everything was fresh and food got delivered to the table warm - which for eggs, as all you Yelpers know - makes a huge difference.  

The service in general was great!  The barista unfortunately seemed completely frazzled and could not handle the crowds.  She was a bit short and snooty - because we asked for something - but everyone else's demeanor, service and mood - was pleasant and helpful and made up for her (let's hope just a) bad day.

I am looking forward to another brunch here, trying something else! Let's hope Ms. Barista was just having a bad day and gets her game to par to facilitate the positive experience.      

Pricing was just right - not too expensive for the quality/variety of food options and level of service.
author: Bhavin M.

description: Almond croissant is flaky and melt in your mouth delightful. The omelet with eggs is not to be missed. The atmosphere is chic Parisian with lots of light and wooden tables that add a touch of authenticity to the home-y feel.
author: Janna C.

description: have only tried their ham & cheese sandwich which was very good and their palmerie/ butterfly cookies very good and butterey.my husband had the same sandwich recently he said it wasn't very good. I guess after it changed hands they started to cut back on quality.
author: Nellie J.

description:
I randomly walked into La Boulangerie Patisserie before grabbing dinner down the street. I was craving a mocha and didn't want to go to Starbucks knowing there probably was a cool cafe around the corner. 

It was about 5pm and it was bustling with San Franciscans.

I wanted a mocha, and my goodness- I got a MOCHA. 
The cashier asked "small or large?" Little did I know, the large is large! 
I got a small, and the boyf got a large. 

I remember looking over to the counter to see if our order was ready yet, but thought- "No, that must not be it; we didn't order soup." 

But alas, that was our order because the large mocha comes in a soup bowl! Very unexpected, totally made my day and made me so giddy.

Other than the largeness of the mocha, it was very tasty. It's topped with the perfect amount of foam (and by perfect I mean perfect for foam mustaches). By the end of the drink, there was real chocolate lining the bottom of the cup/bowl making it rich and delicious.
author: Christine A.

description: It's so packed here all the time, kind of takes the enjoyment out of an afternoon break at the pastry shop. I didn't get to try their coffees, but the pastries were really good. (I had the almond croissant and a cinnamon roll type pastry whose name I've forgotten).
author: Chia L.

description:
The little blue place... you can't miss it! 

When I stepped in, I felt like I had been transported to the streets of Paris - actually. 

We had breakfast here and it was delicious... Did I mention that they serve a breakfast pizza loaded with eggs, cheese and asparagus? Unassuming combination I know - but fabulous together!

Munching on the pizza while sipping orange juice on Parisian style table and chairs in front of the bakery was the icing on the cake. The perfect place to relax, take a breath, people watch, and actually do as the French do - and ENJOY your meal.
author: Anita K.

description:
This is my favorite quick breakfast/ brunch spot in the city. The coffee is delicious and the offer all kinds of milk and sugar. My favorite menu item is the fruit and yogurt with granola- they serve it with honey, which I ask them to not put on mine because it is too sweet. I also like their breakfast sandwich, baked eggs, and just plain rolls. With their rolls they have plenty of jams and nutella to dress it up. 

Along with fabulous food, the wait staff is friendly and there are many tables to sit, although its typically pretty packed.
author: Melissa A.

description:
After the Nike Halfathon we came for breakfast/brunch. My only requirement was that i needed bacon. I ordered the croissant sandwich with bacon, egg, cheese and tomatoes, which was good. The gf had the french toast which was made with bread that was more like a custard with a flour crust.

I don't know if liked it or not, but it was interesting.

Coffee has free refills if you head back to the counter.

The place was busy, but thankfully we found seats outside so that the dog wouldn't have to be left tied to the lamppost.
author: Johnny C.

description: I love the bakery so much that I go to San Francisco especially to go here. They have open faced sandwiches which being a health nut, I love, because I am ingesting less carbs. I love their pastries too. They have sweet and salty ones, and I can always find something to satisfy my cravings. I love their tarts and chocolate croissants. However, I am docking this place a star because this place is a little pricey and also doesn't have wifi. Also, the food is a little heavy, as pastries and sandwiched usually are.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I spent $16 here for a late lunch...and it was only for myself! Way too much money. But it was good. 

I got a smoked salmon salad, white bean cup of soup, and two macroons. Holy crap, it was $$. The smoked salmon salad had some yummy candied walnuts which I enjoyed. The salmon itself was "meh." It was okay, nothing to brag about. I thought the white bean soup was delicious and hearty, especially for the cold SF night it turned out to be. 

Usually their bread is pretty good, but since I came around 4:30ish, it tasted a bit old. But the complementary bar or nutella, jams, jellies, butter, pickles, and etc made it that much better.  

The atmosphere is easy, calming, and great to read a book or paper by yourself  during breakfast or lunch.
author: anita h.

description:
This is a cute spot with a bakery counter that looks so enticing, the wicker chairs have a certain Gallic charm, and the bar at the back, with the wide variety of jams, sugars, cream, milk, cucumber-flavored water, and Dijon mustard (for savory items) is a siren song to my husband. So, today, while waiting for me, he availed himself of the breakfast consisting of yogurt, fruit and granola. He reported that this example was "stellar". He's picky, so I know off the top of my head that this means no bananas, or fruit past its' prime, and the yogurt must have been good quality.

My selection later on was not that great. I ordered a cheese and tomato Crocque Monsieur and it was so-so at best. The woman working behind the counter (who was not too keen on customer service) seemed genuinely put out that I would want it warm. She huffed and puffed all the way to the grill and then just shoved it into a wax-paper bag (thus causing all the cheese  to stick to the paper. Having lived in Paris where rudeness is an art form, this just did not cut it. And, she wasn't French. As if that's an excuse anyway...

So, next time I find myself in this neck o' the woods, I will quite happily  take a "Pass" for this spot, and focus my energies to a friendlier place.  You'll have to check it out for yourselves: Stuart had a fine time, so maybe it's hit or miss. Apparently, I missed.
author: Suzanne F.

description:
I was introduced to this delightful cavity inducing joy by my brother's in-laws.  Usually bakeries do not get me overly excited - I am a chocolate, not a sugar, kind of guy.  Here I will make an exception for Almond Croissants.  

Incredible almond flavor with oozing almond paste goodness shining through the flaky, light croissant exterior.  I recommend a strong cup of black coffee, 1 (or more) of these, and a good book.  The flavors, the sugar, and the caffeine will turn even the most retreaded thriller-wannabe into the next Preston & Child classic.  Love it.
author: Patrick G.

description: So cute! Not super cheap, but so cute and quaint, and my sandwich was amazing, even a couple hours later. I don't know how they managed to make a chain make me feel like I was back in Paris. Kudos to them!
author: Vonetta Y.

description:
I enjoy coming here when I'm in town. I usually get a few sandwiches, macarons etc for my picnic in GGP. They're fresh & ohh soo good. Nice and quick. Cute little place really. 

Correct me if I'm wrong, but I think it's in between 575-535 Columbus St? Same Street as Mara's Italian Pasteries?..
author: Ana C.

description:
----------
One of my favorites. I love the large cups the coffee comes in. Their tiny sandwiches are tasty and their ham sandwich is really good. The atmosphere is perfect. Their flan is relatively good.
author: Mia K.

description:
I looooove this place. Its right by my home and where I work. With short lines this is a great stop for my employee and myself when we are in need of a quick bite and a coffee. With soy milk available without having to ask and wait around for it is refreshing. 
They have bites to eat that are not huge overly sized items. With medium prices I love that I can come again and again.
author: Julia G.

description: I've only been here a couple of times, but it always seems to be jam packed when I do come.  So grab a table - fast!  But the food has been good... service was more of a production line since there were so many people, but it seemed efficient enough.  The first time I had a sandwich with smoked salmon... mm!!!  The last time I had a quiche lorraine which was alright... they didn't offer to heat it up and at room temperature, it was just ok.  But I also had a sticky bun for the road and boy was it good!  Oh and I don't know if it was just for Valentine's Day but there were some delicious looking red velvet cupcakes on display... actually, their whole dessert display, while small, looked scrumptious.  But I didn't get anything... maybe next time!
author: Christine N.

description:
The plave was dirty with flies walking on the pastries
The staff had a bad attitude
This is not french- just bad
author: lisa s.

description:
This is such a cute little bakery with lots of goodies to try.  It gets really crowded but being able to stand in line to order your food helps out a bit.  They have a huge staff behind the counter and bustling between the tables and they're all very friendly and helpful.  

I enjoyed the croissant sandwich with thick-cut bacon, egg, cheese, and tomatoes.  It also came with a side of fresh fruit that went perfectly with the sandwich.  The husband had the open-faced lox sandwich and it was a nice combination of crusty bread topped with cream cheese, cucumber, lox, and capers.  It came with a side salad that made for a satisfying meal as well.  Their coffee is good and will provide you with free refills at the counter.  

This place is a great place to have Sunday brunch with a few friends.  Take a table inside with the crowd or snag one of their 2 or 3 tables outside.  Just arrive early to avoid a long line.
author: Nina L.

description: I guess I'm one of the few to say this place isn't that great. Although, it isn't too bad, I can't say their baked goods are wonderful.  May be I'm a snob when it comes to French bakery but it wasn't the best.
author: Bayarea K.

description: It doesn't take much to please me when you have good coffee and chocolate on hand. Service was slow, despite the moderate traffic, but the food was good as was the coffee.
author: Ron K.

description: My neighborhood favorite for breakfast, brunch, lunch or snack.  The food is great, very reasonably priced, the staff friendly.  The breakfast sandwiches, pastries and lunchtime salads are my favorite--reliably hearty portions.  What you see is what you get.  It is cafeteria style-order, pay, take your number to your table.  The line moves pretty quickly and I have never waited more than 10 minutes.  I think they have a leg up on La Boulangerie on Union, Columbus, or Strawberry Village.
author: Rita G.

description: This was a good little place to grab a bite. It was busy, but we were able to find a table fairly quickly (during lunch time). The salads were fresh and tasty and the service was quick. It was a little cold to sit outside but when the temperature warms up and the sun is out, it would definitely be a seating option!
author: Shaye S.

description: Heavenly pastries. Yummy salads and sandwiches. Delicious coffee drinks.  Wonderful friendly  I'd go every morning if I could !
author: Henry H.

description: The mimosa's were strong and the almond croissant tasty, can't wait for more!
author: Erica C.

description: This is easily one of my favorite places to get macarons in the city! The lovely staff here hooked up a giftbox of 16 macarons for the price of 8. Their almond croissants are so delicious! Parking can be difficult at times but its not top bad.
author: Tesa B.

description: I cant stop coming here! The pastry all of it is the best ever! I love this place because you can have a great quality pastry and your cofffe and you're good to go! This is a nice place to just chill on your day off! The fruit bowl with honey is very good too.
author: Melissa M.

description: everything is good here. by the time i'm done with class the cakes are all gone! i love their strong coffee and the fact that i can read or study without feeling guilty about takin up a table. the workers are friendly and i love the jar of jam and nutella they have set up at the condiments table!
author: Erin M.

description: The address or the map on yelp somehow showed a wrong location - a little off from the actual location, I think. It was at the Union St. x Pork, not at the Van Ness. I loved this European style cafe. We ordered open-face sandwiches and a bowl of soup for lunch. I loved them very much. They were freshly made, tasteful, and satisfactory. Their french flies were also great. We ended up have desserts too and a big cup of coffee. We were happy that we accidentally found this wonderful cafe in SF. We will definitely go back there.
author: Miwa Y.

description: the food is good most of the time.  the service is not.  the employees are more interested in chatting with each other than doing their job of helping customers.  the order is usually not right after a long wait so then it is not worth having it corrected.  it is convenient...which keeps me coming back.
author: A E.

description: oh em gee.  Yes, overpriced, but sooooooo good... especially their little sandwich cookies in different flavors.... what are those called, macaroons?  Madaleines?
author: Dawn N.
